results.title: Indonesian cuisine
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Education Dept. Curriculum Branch and Ivan Gaal
results.brief_description: Focusing on a family of Indonesian immigrants and their Indonesian student guest, this program shows how Indonesians in Australia seek to preserve their culture through their cuisine and through cultural events which demonstrate their music, dress and customs.

results.title: Indonesian conversations
results.creator_credit: University of Western Sydney and Marisa Sara
results.brief_description: Ten short segments dramatise a typical situation in which a tourist may find themselves whilst travelling in Indonesia. The purpose is to present aspects of colloquial language in a meaningful context. Scripted conversations include asking directions, visiting a post office, buying food and snacks and eating in a warung. It should be noted that the language and expressions are “real life” Indonesian from the city of Yogyakarta. Students will also gain some appreciation of the cultural differences between Australia and Indonesia. Accompanied by a Study Guide.

results.title: Indonesian boomerang
results.creator_credit: Ridley Williams and Donald R. Ham
results.brief_description: A Sydney schoolteacher visits Indonesia to study the language and culture and returns with a new awareness of the problems of developing countries. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Indonesia: time to grow
results.brief_description: This film centres on the trip to the market of an Indonesian farmer, Sukanta, and his ten year old son, Djuki. They live in a village four miles from the rapidly growing city of Jakarta. Farm and village life are seen in reflective scenes, and city life is seen through the eyes of Djuki as he accompanies his elder brother, Suriana, a scholarship student at the university, on a walking tour of Jakarta.

results.title: Indonesia: time of transition
results.creator_credit: Beaumaris Film Productions and Peter Drummond
results.brief_description: A look at the contrasts to be found in Indonesia. Shows life in Djakarta, the island of Bali, subsistence farming, and Western influences on the traditional culture. Mentions the new spirit of nationalism, the role of the students and the high birth rate. Interviews two military commanders who talk about the political situation.

results.title: Indonesia: the land and the people
results.brief_description: A survey of the Republic of Indonesia, including its geographical location, weather, soil, and agriculture. Mention is made of the population, of the different religions, languages, and crafts; the unique life with dancing and music daily, the use of the market place, and the cluster of homes of members of one clan. Products of the country are pictured and stress placed on importance of foreign trade.

results.title: Indonesia: new nation of Asia
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and William Deneen
results.brief_description: An Indonesian teacher tells the story of his country. Traces the history of Indonesia from Dutch rule to independence; shows life in crowded cities and in the home of village families; examines the natural resources, religions, art and industries of the country, pointing out how living standards are improving.

results.title: Indonesia calling
results.creator_credit: Waterside Workers' Federation of Australia. Film Unit. and Joris Ivens
results.brief_description: Appointed as film commissioner to the Dutch Indies, it was intended that Ivens would create educational films on behalf of the Dutch government and would document the liberation of Indonesia from Japanese occupation. When it became obvious that the Dutch government had no interest in granting independance to Indonesia, Ivens resigned. Working clandestinely, he recorded this film in support of the struggle by the Indonesian people to gain their independance. The film shows efforts by Australian dockworkers and striking Indonesian seamen to prevent the shipment of arms and ammunition to Indonesia aboard Dutch vessels. Cinematography, Marion Michelle. Editing, Joris Ivens and Jock Levy. Script, Joris Ivens and Catherine Duncan. Commentary, Peter Finch.

results.title: Indonesia builds a better life
results.brief_description: Indonesia, since gaining independence, has begun a series of new developments. Thousands of men and women are being taught to read and write as part of a campaign to eradicate illiteracy. An attempt is being made to control the spread of the disease Framboesia, commonly known as yaws. Those already suffering from the disease are given on the spot treatment. While this medical attention is being given research workers are constantly checking its results, and reporting to the World Health Organisation.

results.title: Indochine [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Paradis Films, La Generale D'Images, Bac Films (France), Orly Films, Cine 5, Eric Heumann, Jean Labadie and Regis Wargnier
results.brief_description: Set in 1930 in French Indochina, on the cusp of revolution, the 1993 Academy Award Winning Best Foreign Film, “Indochine” is the epic story of two women; a French mother and her adopted Indochinese daughter. Their relationship survives social and cultural obstacles, but is ultimately stretched to extremes by their passionate love for the same man. The awesome beauty of Vietnam provides a perfect backdrop for this splendid film. Catherine Deneuve gives a “tour de force” performance. In French with English subtitles.
